page.title: 19Rochford Market Square
page.content: Traditionally there has always been a market in Rochford Square for hundreds of years. In fact, in the Square everything important happened; The Great Fire of 1820, the bonfire to celebrate the relief of Mafeking, the site of the old pump with queues of people drawing water, the sale of wool from the Market Hall, market day on Thursday with a cattle sale every other week, executions, circuses, fairs and local assemblies. Nowadays it is quiet in comparison. Market days are Wednesday and Saturday. There is a wet fish stall, a cheese stall, a pet stall, numerous clothes stalls and fruit and vegetable stalls, all set up in the square. The total number seldom exceeds twelve. Gone are the saddlers, watchmakers and candlemakers and in their place are banks, a post office, a library and also a supermarket.
